ol.li: Understand the definition of a basis of a subspace.
Recipes: basis for a column space, basis for a null space, basis of a span.
Picture: basis of a subspace of \R^2 or \R^3.

subsection.title: Basis of a Subspace
subsection.p: As we discussed in , a subspace is the same as a span, except we do not have a set of spanning vectors in mind. There are infinitely many choices of spanning sets for a nonzero subspace; to avoid redundancy, usually it is most convenient to choose a spanning set with the minimal number of vectors in it. This is the idea behind the notion of a basis.

statement.p:
Let V be a subspace of \R^n. A basis of V is a set of vectors \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} in V such that:
V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\}, and
the set \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} is linearly independent.

subsection.p: Recall that a set of vectors is linearly independent if and only if, when you remove any vector from the set, the span shrinks (). In other words, if \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} is a basis of a subspace V, then no proper subset of \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} will span V: it is a minimal spanning set. Any subspace admits a basis by this .

bluebox.p: A nonzero subspace has infinitely many different bases, but they all contain the same number of vectors.

subsection.p: We leave it as an exercise to prove that any two bases have the same number of vectors; one might want to wait until after learning the invertible matrix theorem in .

statement.p: Let V be a subspace of \R^n. The number of vectors in any basis of V is called the dimension of V, and is written \dim V.

example.p:
One shows exactly as in the above that the standard coordinate vectors e_1=\vec{1 0 \vdots, 0 0},\quad e_2=\vec{0 1 \vdots, 0 0}, \quad\ldots,\quad e_{n-1}=\vec{0 0 \vdots, 1 0},\quad e_n=\vec{0 0 \vdots, 0 1}

specialcase.p:
The previous implies that any basis for \R^n has n vectors in it. Let v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n be vectors in \R^n, and let A be the n\times n matrix with columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n.
To say that \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n\} spans \R^n means that A has a pivot position in every row: see this .
To say that \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n\} is linearly independent means that A has a pivot position in every column: see this .
Since A is a square matrix, it has a pivot in every row if and only if it has a pivot in every column. We will see in that the above two conditions are equivalent to the invertibility of the matrix A.

statement.p: Let V = \left\{ \vec{x y z} \text{ in } \R^3\bigm| x + 3y + z = 0 \right\} \qquad \cB = \left\{ \vec{-3 1 0},\;\vec{0 1 -3} \right\}. Verify that V is a subspace, and show directly that \cB is a basis for V.

figure.caption: A picture of the plane V and its basis \cB = \{v_1,v_2\}. Note that \cB spans V and is linearly independent.

solution.p: This example is somewhat contrived, in that we will learn systematic methods for verifying that a subset is a basis. The intention is to illustrate the defining properties of a basis.

subsection.title: Computing a Basis for a Subspace
subsection.p: Now we show how to find bases for the column space of a matrix and the null space of a matrix. In order to find a basis for a given subspace, it is usually best to rewrite the subspace as a column space or a null space first: see this .

paragraphs.title: A basis for the column space
paragraphs.p: First we show how to compute a basis for the column space of a matrix.

statement.p: The pivot columns of a matrix A form a basis for \Col(A).

proof.p: This is a restatement of a .

statement.p: The dimension of \Col(A) is the number of pivots of A.

paragraphs.title: A basis of a span
paragraphs.p: Basisof a span Spanbasis ofBasis Computing a basis for a span is the same as computing a basis for a column space. Indeed, the span of finitely many vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m is the column space of a matrix, namely, the matrix A whose columns are v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m: A = \mat{| | ,, |; v_1 v_2 \cdots, v_m; | | ,, |}.

statement.p: Find a basis of the subspace V = \Span\left\{\vec{1 -2 2},\;\vec{2 -3 4},\;\vec{0 4 0},\;\vec{-1 5 -2}\right\}.

solution.p: The subspace V is the column space of the matrix A = \mat[r]{1 2 0 -1; -2 -3 4 5; 2 4 0 -2}. The reduced row echelon form of this matrix is \mat[r]{1 0 -8 -7; 0 1 4 3; 0 0 0 0}. The first two columns are pivot columns, so a basis for V is \left\{\vec{1 -2 2},\;\vec{2 -3 4}\right\}.

figure.caption: A picture of the plane V and its basis \cB = \{v_1,v_2\}.

example.title: Another basis of the same span

solution.p: The point of this example is that the above gives one basis for V; as always, there are infinitely more.

Reordering the vectors, we can express V as the column space of A' = \mat[r]{0 -1 1 2; 4 5 -2 -3; 0 -2 2 4}. The reduced row echelon form of this matrix is \mat{1 0 3/4 7/4; 0 1 -1 -2; 0 0 0 0}. The first two columns are pivot columns, so a basis for V is \left\{\vec{0 4 0},\;\vec{-1 5 -2}\right\}. These are the last two vectors in the given spanning set.

figure.caption: A picture of the plane V and its basis \cB = \{v_1,v_2\}.

paragraphs.title: A basis for the null space
paragraphs.p: In order to compute a basis for the null space of a matrix, one has to find the parametric vector form of the solutions of the homogeneous equation Ax=0.

statement.p: The vectors attached to the free variables in the parametric vector form of the solution set of Ax=0 form a basis of \Nul(A).

paragraphs.p: The proof of the theorem has two parts. The first part is that every solution lies in the span of the given vectors. This is automatic: the vectors are exactly chosen so that every solution is a linear combination of those vectors. The second part is that the vectors are linearly independent. This part was discussed in this .

paragraphs.title: A basis for a general subspace
paragraphs.p: As mentioned at the beginning of this subsection, when given a subspace written in a different form, in order to compute a basis it is usually best to rewrite it as a column space or null space of a matrix.

statement.p:
Let V be the subspace defined by
V = \left\{\vec{x y z}\bigm| x + 2y = z\right\}.
Find a basis for V. What is \dim(V)?

solution.p: First we notice that V is exactly the solution set of the homogeneous linear equation x + 2y - z = 0. Hence V = \Nul\mat{1 2 -1}. This matrix is in reduced row echelon form; the parametric form of the general solution is x = -2y + z, so the parametric vector form is \vec{x y z} = y\vec{-2 1 0} + z\vec{1 0 1}. It follows that a basis is \left\{\vec{-2 1 0},\;\vec{1 0 1}\right\}. Since V has a basis with two vectors, its dimension is 2: it is a plane.

subsection.title: The Basis Theorem
subsection.p: Recall that \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n\} forms a basis for \R^n if and only if the matrix A with columns v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n has a pivot in every row and column (see this ). Since A is an n\times n matrix, these two conditions are equivalent: the vectors span if and only if they are linearly independent. The basis theorem is an abstract version of the preceding statement, that applies to any subspace.

statement.p:
Let V be a subspace of dimension m. Then:
Any m linearly independent vectors in V form a basis for V.
Any m vectors that span V form a basis for V.

proof.p: Suppose that \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} is a set of linearly independent vectors in V. In order to show that \cB is a basis for V, we must prove that V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\}. If not, then there exists some vector v_{m+1} in V that is not contained in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\}. By the increasing span criterion, the set \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m,v_{m+1}\} is also linearly independent. Continuing in this way, we keep choosing vectors until we eventually do have a linearly independent spanning set: say V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m,\ldots,v_{m+k}\}. Then \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{m+k}\} is a basis for V, which implies that \dim(V) = m+k > m. But we were assuming that V has dimension m, so \cB must have already been a basis.

Now suppose that \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} spans V. If \cB is not linearly independent, then by this , we can remove some number of vectors from \cB without shrinking its span. After reordering, we can assume that we removed the last k vectors without shrinking the span, and that we cannot remove any more. Now V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{m-k}\}, and \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_{m-k}\} is a basis for V because it is linearly independent. This implies that \dim V=m-k < m. But we were assuming that \dim V = m, so \cB must have already been a basis.

subsection.p:
In other words, if you already know that \dim V = m, and if you have a set of m vectors \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} in V, then you only have to check one of:
\cB is linearly independent, or
\cB spans V,
in order for \cB to be a basis of V. If you did not already know that \dim V = m, then you would have to check both properties.

To put it yet another way, suppose we have a set of vectors \cB = \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_m\} in a subspace V. Then if any two of the following statements is true, the third must also be true:
\cB is linearly independent,
\cB spans V, and
\dim V = m.
For example, if V is a plane, then any two noncollinear vectors in V form a basis.

example.title: Two noncollinear vectors form a basis of a plane

solution.p:
We know from the previous examples that \dim V = 2. By the , it suffices to find any two noncollinear vectors in V. We write two linear combinations of the four given spanning vectors, chosen at random:
w_1 = \vec{1 -2 2} + \vec{2 -3 4} = \vec{3 -5 6} \qquad w_2 = -\vec{2 -3 4} + \frac 12\vec{0 4 0} = \vec{-2 5 -4}.
Since w_1,w_2 are not collinear, \cB = \{w_1,w_2\} is a basis for V.

figure.caption: A picture of the plane V and its basis \cB = \{w_1,w_2\}.

solution.p:
First note that V is the null space of the matrix \mat{1 1 -1}; this matrix is in reduced row echelon form and has two free variables, so V is indeed a plane. We write down two vectors satisfying x_1 + x_2 = x_3:
v_1 = \vec{1 0 1} \qquad v_2 = \vec{0 1 1}.
Since v_1 and v_2 are not collinear, they are linearly independent; since \dim(V) = 2, the basis theorem implies that \{v_1,v_2\} is a basis for V.
